column1: Hi,My family and I are traveling to Bali from the UK transiting via Singapore. We are obviously concerned about catching the coronavirus at either the airport or our onward flight to Bali (and back again). Was wondering if any Singaporeans had any ideas of what precautions have been put in place?Thank you.

There you go fellaENHANCED PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES AT JEWEL CHANGI AIRPORTIn light of the current 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) situation, Jewel Changi Airport has stepped up and implemented the following precautionary measures:  1) Temperature screening for all staff before the start and end of each shift. Staff with fever & flu-like symptoms will be asked to seek immediate medical treatment. 2) Deploy hand sanitisers at all concierge counters and Canopy Park attractions. 3) Staff will monitor closely for guests looking unwell and urge them to seek medical consultation at the nearest clinic at Terminal 3. Masks will also be provided to the guests.  4) Cleaning regimes and disinfection efforts have also been intensified. For the latest updates by the Ministry of Health (MOH), please refer to www.moh.gov.sg/2019-ncov-wuhan

ADVISORY ON 2019 NOVEL CORONAVIRUSIn light of the evolving situation on the 2019 novel coronavirus, Singapore’s Ministry of Health has issued the following travel advisory for passengers arriving in Singapore: New visitors with travel history in mainland Chinai. From 1 February 2020, 11:59 pm, all new visitors with recent travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days will not be allowed entry into Singapore or transit through Singapore.ii. With immediate effect, the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority will suspend the issuance of all forms of new visas to those with PRC passports. Singapore’s status as a visa-free transit facility for those with PRC passports will also be suspended.iii. Previously issued short-term and multiple-visit visas for those with PRC passports will also be suspended. During this period of suspension, they will not be allowed entry into Singapore. Returning residents and long-term pass holders with travel history in mainland Chinai. With immediate effect, the following returning groups will be issued an advisory for them to be placed on a 14-day leave of absence from the day of their return from China: a. Residents (Singapore Citizens/PRs) with recent travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days; and b. Long-term pass holders (including Work Passes and Permits, Student Pass, Dependent Pass and Long-term Visit Pass) Temperature screening i. Passengers on all arrival flights at Changi and Seletar Airports are subject to temperature screening. As an additional measure by Changi Airport, passengers on all departure flights at Changi will also be subject to temperature screening.ii. For inbound flights from China, healthcare teams will be at the aerobridges to identify passengers who look unwell because fever may not be present for all cases.iii. Passengers who feel unwell should report to the health screening stations located in each terminal. For the latest updates by MOH, please refer to www.moh.gov.sg/2019-ncov-wuhanENHANCED PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES AT CHANGI AIRPORTIn light of the 2019-nCoV situation, Changi Airport has stepped up and implemented the following precautionary measures across the four terminals:  More hand sanitisers installedMore hand sanitisers have been installed across the four terminals in both the public and transit areas for the convenience of passengers and the airport community. Increased frequency in cleaning and disinfecting of high contact areasHigh contact areas, such as the following, are cleaned and disinfected more frequently:door knobs and handleshandrails (e.g. travellators, escalators, lift)counter tops (e.g. immigration counters, information counters, check-in counters)taxi queue and bus berth railingswater coolerstrolleyswheelchairsbaby strollerstables at F&B outletsTouchscreen panels around the airport have been sprayed with a protective coating to reduce surface contamination while self-order kiosks at F&B outlets are cleaned and disinfected regularly.Bins are also emptied more frequently. More frequent cleaning of toilets and carpetsToilet bowls are cleaned more frequently, along with the emptying of bins and wiping of sinks and counter tops.Toilet flush buttons, door knobs, grab bars, toilet paper dispensers and seat sanitiser dispensers are cleaned and disinfected more frequently.Carpets in the Transit Hall are vacuumed with an increased frequency.Additional wet vacuuming will also be done. Cleaning of air-conditioning systemAir Handling Unit (AHU) filters will be replaced more frequently with the cooling coil washed more frequently.Increased circulation of fresh air in the terminals via the air-conditioning system.
Bottom line - safe as can be, however, remain vigilant yourself ! Safe travels pal
Hi,Thanks Bill, departure date for us is 6/5/20 so sometime before we will need to make a decision. Take care.
I’m also travelling through Singapore (transit 5 hours) to India. But I heard Singapore has banned transit entry too? But the airlines are still taking the bookings. What about you?

RageshEmperumal, transits are not allowed for non-residents and I don’t think it will be lifted in the near future.You will need to change your booking or defer your trip. https://www.ica.gov.sg/covid-19Edited: 2:31 pm, April 15, 2020
